relation: Access Log Rotation / Server Log Rotation. Select any or both of these options to configure rotation for that log type.

The configured time when the event will start. Select the hour and minutes value from the drop-down box. Every Day — Starts the event specified every day at the specified time. Specific Days — Starts the event specified at specific days. 1. Days — Specify any day from Sunday to Saturday. 2. Dates — Specify any day of the month from 1 to 31 as comma separated entries. E.g. 4,23,9 Specific Months — Starts the event specified at the specific time and month. Specify month from January to December.
Start the specified event after this time period. 1. Every Hours — Select the number of hours from the drop-down box. 2. Every Seconds — Select the number of seconds from the drop-down box.
pageTitle: Chapter 13 Monitoring Your Server (Sun Java System Web Server 7.0 Update 7 Administrator's Guide)
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {34794=The preceding command displays the Server Logs of a given configuration between the date 01/Jan/2006:09:00:00 and 04/Jan/2006:10:00:00., 34593=wadm> get-log --user=admin --password-file=admin.passwd --host=localhost --port=8989 --start-date=01/01/2006:09:00:00 --end-date=04/01/2006:10:00:00 --config=test cat.test.com, 41975=For example, you can set up files to rotate every hour, and the server saves and names the file “access.199907.0152400,” where “name|year|month|day|24-hour time” is concatenated together into a single character string. The exact format of the access log archive file varies depending upon which type of log rotation you set up., 27468=smuxpeer 1.3.6.1.4.1.42.2.190.1, 27519=view systemview included .1.3.6.1.4.1.42.2.190.1, 44843=Specific Months — Starts the event specified at the specific time and month. Specify month from January to December.}
textBeforeTable: Table 13–1 Monitoring Categories Virtual Server Statistics Instance Statistics General Statistics The server statistics can be viewed across the following categories: Monitoring The Server Statistics Response Time Statistics Error Statistics Request Statistics Click the configuration name to see the configuration level statistics. The general statistics are divided into three types: Response Time — The maximum response time for any of the virtual servers. Errors — Total number of errors logged across all virtual servers. Requests — Total number of requests received across all virtual servers. Nodes — The number of nodes in which the configuration has been deployed. To monitor server parameters at the configuration level, click Monitoring > Configurations tab. The table lists the available configuration along with the following information: View error/access log at the instance level. Enable/Disable monitoring at configuration level. View server statistics at an instance and configuration level. From the Sun Java System Web Server Administration Console, you can perform the following actions: The server parameters that can be monitored are displayed when you select the Configurations or Instances tab under the monitoring parent tab. Monitoring Capabilities in Sun Java System Web Server Configuring Log Settings for Administration
textAfterTable: Viewing The Statistics Click the Monitoring tab. Select the configuration from the list. View General, Instance and Virtual Server Statistics. Note – Using CLI You can monitor the server using the get-config-stats, get-virtual-serevr-stats, get-webapp-stats and get-servlet-stats commands. wadm> get-config-stats --user=admin --password-file=admin.passwd --host=localhost --port=8989 --config=test --node=cat.test.com --ssl=true The preceding command will fetch the statistics for the given instance. To see the statistics at the configuration level, the above command can be used without the --node option. wadm> get-virtual-server-stats --user=admin --password-file=admin.passwd --host=localhost --port=8989 --config=test --vs=www.test.com --node=cat.test.com --ssl=true The preceding command will fetch the aggregated virtual server statistics for a given configuration across all the nodes where the configuration has been deployed. To see the statistics for a configuration deployed on a given node --node option can be used. wadm> get-webapp-stats --user=admin --password-file=admin.passwd --host=localhost --port=8989 --config=test --node=cat.test.com --vs=www.test.com --uri=/foo --ssl=true The preceding command will fetch the statistics for a given web application deployed on the given virtual server of the given instance. To see the aggregated web application statistics for a given configuration across all the nodes where the configuration has been deployed, the previous command can be used without the --node option. wadm> get-servlet-stats --user=admin --password-file=admin.pwd --host=localhost --port=8989 --config=test --node=cat.test.com --vs=www.test.com
